body: William Forsythe, the American choreographer who has been artistic director of the Frankfurt Ballet in Germany since 1984, is a prodigious talent but no prodigal son. He refuses to come home. title: DANCE REVIEW; Forces of Order And Disorder

title: DANCE REVIEW; A Hovering Self, Not Man or Woman

title: THEATER REVIEW; A Classic Russian Tale of Infidelity, Sparely Told

title: More Than Just a Movie House; A Magnet for Brooklyn's Young Is in Place, but Will It Work?

body: STAPLETON, Staten Island, resembles nothing so much as a Tennessee Williams diva: a faded beauty critically short on cash. title: MAKING IT WORK; Belgium's Window on Staten Island

body: The driver of a truck that ran over a Brooklyn boy on Tuesday has been given a summons for taking the 18-wheeler on a street where commercial traffic is banned, the police said. The boy, Quinntaun Burns, 7, later died of his injuries. He was riding his bicycle a few blocks from his home on South Portland Avenue in Fort Greene when the accident
title: Truck Driver Gets Summons After Boy Dies In an Accident

body: It was an unseasonably warm fall Saturday, but Imani Webb had donned her Teflon coat. title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE GRASS ROOTS; New Party Is Courting Liberal Constituencies

body: For a place as wildly diverse as New York, the city's major commercial theater can often seem considerably less so. title: Amid Diversity Onstage, Passion's a Mother Tongue

title: Betty Carter, Innovative Jazz Vocalist, Is Dead at 69

body: ''Julius Caesar'' makes no mention of a wino. A Poet, yes; a Soothsayer, of course. But there is no reference in Shakespeare to a tipsy guy in soiled clothes who heckles Cassius and wheezes during Marc Antony's funeral oration. And yet here he was on a recent evening, an attention-drawing spectator teetering noisily in his cups, stage right, as the
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Summer Theater: Out of Doors and Off the Wall

body: The wide world beyond the small one in which she has always lived beckons through the fog, as tempting as it is unknown. For Imogen, the sorely tried heroine of Shakespeare's ''Cymbeline,'' this shadowy future can't arrive quickly enough. ''O, for a horse with wings!'' she exclaims, and it's impossible not to share her exhilaration and impatience.
title: THEATER REVIEW; Trying to Broaden the Appeal of Shakespeare, Even at His Least Digestible

body: In the Royal Shakespeare Company's revival of ''Everyman,'' the 15th-century morality play, Beauty wears one red high heel, Strength sports a weight lifter's belt and Goods flashes a wad of bills. title: THEATER REVIEW; A Lively, Modern Step on That Not-So-Dreadful Journey

body: He's Krapp, all right: the white hair, arranged like errant strands of cotton candy; the scarlet nose, evidence of a requited love of the bottle; the shuffling feet, the frantic hands and, of course, the haunted, probing eyes, fixed on that ancient tape recorder and the plastic spools that safeguard the secrets of a solitary life. title: THEATER REVIEW; Haunted by Hope and Regret on Eternal Playback

title: THEATER REVIEW; Political Spin Decked in Royal Trappings

body: A Brooklyn man claiming to be a cabdriver robbed and tried to rape a woman he picked up as a fare yesterday, the police said. The man, Bernard Brown, 32, of Clinton Avenue in Fort Greene, was captured because his victim grabbed a cellular telephone from the car and escaped down the street, said Lieut. Stephen Biegel, a Police Department spokesman.
title: Cell Phone Leads to Suspect in Sex Attack

title: Haitian Art Bursting Out

body: To the Editor: As a recent Brooklyn home buyer, I could appreciate ''For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar'' (front page, April 1). title: The Middle Class Can Live Here

body: Along Came a Spider Q. I recall reports of a child in Queens being bitten by a black widow spider, back in the 1950's. Are they still found in the city? A. Although rarely seen, at least two species of black widow spiders, Latrodectus variolus and Latrodectus mactans, are indigenous to our area, according to Louis N. Sorkin, an arachnologist at the
title: F.Y.I.

body: Todd Neuhaus, an advertising executive, and his wife, Christina, didn't want much. They wanted to rent a Manhattan apartment for less than $3,000 with a bedroom for themselves and one for their two boys. They wanted it to be near good public schools, because private school was beyond their means. Most of all, the Neuhauses wanted to believe it
title: For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar

body: BACK when East New York seemed more like West Hell, Betty Peterson-Williams heard of new homes sprouting up there and in Brownsville. The houses were squat, but not without charm -- for about $50,000, they offered renters the chance to become homeowners while sweeping away the carpet of rubble that covered many blocks in the Brooklyn neighborhoods
title: About New York; A Project Called Hope, Unrealized

body: After a last-minute dispute with City Hall was resolved, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved the renovation of Brooklyn's busiest rail terminal, the combined Long Island Rail Road and subway station at Atlantic Avenue and Flatbush Avenue, and the construction of a large shopping mall above it. title: Plan Ratified for Mall at L.I.R.R. Terminal

body: In fits and starts over several decades, Park Slope has become a laboratory for both assimilation and gentrification. The Irish and the Italians once brawled on Fifth Avenue, followed by the Puerto Ricans, who elbowed into the mix. There were Jamaicans, and by the 1970's, the hippies had arrived, enticed by the lure of stately but inexpensive
title: Park Slope, Reshaped by Money; As Rents and Prices Rise, Some Fear for Neighborhood's Soul

body: Restaurants from Southeast Asia range from the familiar to the exotic. title: EATING OUT; Southeast Asian Fare

title: THEATER REVIEW; The Sisters Return, Withdrawn and Steely

body: One part black art survey and one part eclectic art bazaar, the National Black Fine Art Show returned to the Puck Building in SoHo yesterday for its second annual show. The fair bills itself as the first major black art fair in the United States, and last year, its sponsors said, it attracted 10,000 people. This year there are 41 booths
title: Black Art Show's Goals: Recognition and Buyers

body: To the French Canadian playwright Michel Marc Bouchard, an abused child is the most desperate of prisoners: he has no escape. So it is not surprising that when choosing a pet for Maurice, the mistreated boy in ''Tale of Teeka,'' he decided to use a creature incapable of freedom: a farm goose. ''I wanted an animal that was pure and naive,'' Mr.
title: FAMILY FARE; A Story of a Boy And His Goose

body: Some say that given the fluidity of today's economy and the pace of technological change, people should no longer cling to the idea of having one job for life. title: Classical Musicians Team Up With Actors In the AIDS Battle

body: Lashawn Israel Chambers liked to look out on the waters of the East River from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, watching the ships go by. ''I'm going to be something,'' he told school friends he grew up with in the Walt Whitman Houses in Fort Greene. ''I'm going to get out.'' And so he did, moving a year ago to Baltimore, where he got his own place and was
title: Home for Holidays, a 21-Year-Old Man Is the Year's First Homicide Victim
